Catalyst and Advanced Materials Research Laboratory Chemical Engineering Department Faculty of Engineering University of Kashan Kashan Iran This paper describes the properties and performance of the Ni/MgO catalysts fabricated via the surfactant-aided co-precipitation technique by diverse precipitants like PVA, CTAB, and PVP. Among the surfactants adopted, PVA was the most effective and indicated a high catalytic potential of about 60 % at 600 °C with GHSV of 24,000 mL/g.h. The XRD, BET, SEM-EDX, H2-TPR, TPO, and Raman techniques were extensively applied to estimate the structural properties of the as-prepared catalysts. The other goal of this study was the evaluation of the effect of the promotion of Ni-based catalysts by selected rare earth metals, Y (2.5 5, 10 wt%) and Gd, on the activity of Ni/MgO catalyst in the methane decomposition process, which has not been widely investigated in this process. The obtained results revealed that the Gd promoter did not provide structural and performance advantages. The results of the BET area related to the introduction of promoters showed that the 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst possesses a large surface area (64.7 m2/g), low pore size (13.8 nm), and crystal size (16.1 nm). The result also displays that a maximum CH4 conversion of about 75 % was obtained for this sample at 675 °C and has an excellent lifetime in 300 min of reaction. In addition, the Raman spectra indicated the attendance of the ordered filamentous carbon with nice crystallinity on the bed of the 50Ni-5Y/MgO. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CH4 decomposition Ni/MgO Co-precipitation Surfactant Promoters Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The rising anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions, high dependency on fossil fuels, and the diminution of petroleum-based reserves have led scientists to focus on using hydrogen as an environmentally friendly fuel [1,2]. Thermocatalytic decomposition of methane (CH4 → C+2H2 Δ H=74.5 kJ/mol) has attracted much attention due to producing carbon oxides-free hydrogen as a hopeful energy resource [3]. The metals Fe, Co, and Ni are the most common for this reaction. Ni catalysts present supreme performance and lifetime [4]. Different materials, including SiO2, MgO, Al2O3, TiO2, or mixed oxides, have been extensively examined as support for the methane decomposition reaction [5–10]. Many researchers reported that Ni/MgO is an active catalyst for this reaction because of its small particle sizes, high thermal resistance, and affordability [11]. For instance, Pudukudy et al. [12] studied the Fe/MgO and Ni/MgO and obtained H2 yields equal to 40 %, 38 %, and 46 % at 700, 800, and 900 °C, respectively. Rastegarpanah et al. [13] fabricated four types of supports (e.g., Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, and MgO). Based on their results, the Ni/MgO represented the better performance of 65 % conversion at 600 °C. However, Ni-supported catalysts experience a decrement in durability owing to extensive deposited carbon and Ni particle sintering, hence the need to improve their performance/stability by using promoters [14]. Modifying the supported Ni catalyst with another metal as a dopant (Co, La, Fe, Ce, Cu, Pd, Rh, Pd, Ir, and Pt) is considered one of the basic solutions [7]. Anjaneyulu et al. [15] reported the dissociation of CH4 by the rare earth like RE= La, Pr, Nd, Gd, and Sm on Ni-Al2O3 catalysts at a molar proportion of Ni: RE: Al=2:0.1:0.9 at 550 °C. They stated that the Ni-La and Ni-Gd samples performed better with initial CH4 conversion of 45 % and 40 %, respectively. Furthermore, their study displayed a powerful metal-Al2O3 interaction in the RE-doped models, which is an agent that suppresses the growth of active components and increases efficiency. In another research, Zhan et al. [16] tested the effect of K, Mg, Y, and Ce metals for Ni/Al2O3 in the CH4 dry reforming. The outcomes represented that introducing Y2O3 led to the greatest performances, about 66% at 700 °C during 100 h, owing to improved BET area and Ni dispersion. The literature review reveals that Gd possesses a powerful interaction with Ni addition as spin-orbit interaction (4f-3d charge transfer) between Gd and nickel, which prevented the formation of NiAl2O4 phases [17,18]. Al-Fatesh et al. [19] showed that adding 0.1 wt% Gd over the Ni/MCM-41 catalyst caused retention of the size of active metal nickel before and after the reaction, easy reducibility, high surface area, leading to a high catalytic performance in the dry reforming of methane. Sarkar et al. [17] indicated that a 0.2 wt% Gd-doped ZSM-5-supported Ni catalyst led to the formation of the GdNi5 phase, which inhibited the agglomeration of nickel particles. They stated that Ni-Gd/ZSM-5 catalyst is stable till 100 h without any deactivation in dry reforming of methane. The investigation of the effect of adding Gd on the catalytic properties of Ni/Y2O3+ZrO2 in the CH4 dry reforming was studied by Fakeeha et al. [18]. In this case, the 5 %Ni-4 %Gd/Y+Zr catalyst exhibited a stable ∼80 % H2 yield for 24 h at 800 °C which was owing to modifying the surface by formation of the cubic zirconium gadolinium oxide phase, limiting the NiO size, and making reducible NiO moderately interacted particles available over the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the synthesis method is another important factor affecting the activity of the catalyst. Various synthesis techniques like co-precipitation, impregnation, microwave-assisted combustion, surfactant-assisted precipitation, and sol-gel methods have been considered for the fabrication of catalysts. Among these synthesis techniques, the co-precipitation method, because of its simplicity and low time consumption, is one of the most common methods for the synthesis of catalysts. To improve the performance of the catalysts by this method, the use of surfactants in the co-precipitation process has attracted significant attention [20,21]. However, current studies are insufficient on the impact of the use of surfactants on CH4 decomposition. Shen and Lua [22], in part of their work, checked out the effect of the surfactant polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and showed that the Ni-Cu/CNT model made in the attendance of PVP has the prime activity along with a permanent conversion=0.8 and a carbon yield =616 gC/gNi at 700 °C. They also proved that the presence of PVP molecules with adsorption of the crystal seeds can create a decline in the growth of the particles. Rastegarpanah et al. [23] investigated the influence of incorporating PVP, P123, and CTAB using a one-pot evaporation-induced self-assembly process. They concluded that these surfactants did not markedly affect the activity of the 55 %Ni/2MgO.Al2O3 catalyst. According to the literature, the influence of using rare earth metals such as Y and Gd has not been sufficiently investigated on the physicochemical properties and performance of methane decomposition catalysts. More investigation into hydrogen production through methane decomposition is needed. Therefore, the present work aims to improve the performance of the Ni/MgO catalyst by utilizing Gd2O3 and Y2O3 promoters, especially at high temperatures. In this regard, the present research initially checked the effect of different surfactants such as PVA, CTAB, and PVP in the preparation of Ni/MgO catalyst via the surfactant-aided co-precipitation method in detail to find the proper surfactant for the next step of the study, i.e., the investigate of the role of rare metals as promoters. The effect of (gas hourly space velocity) GHSV and feed ratio was also perused. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The surfactant-assisted co-precipitation procedure [23] was employed for the synthesis of the 50 %Ni/MgO catalyst using three different precipitating agents: CTAB (C19H42BrN, Merck), PVP (Merck) and PVA (Merck). In a typical procedure, in the first stage, about 2 g of each surfactant was dissolved in 200 mL of water and under vigorous stirring at 90 °C to form a transparent solution. After that, about 6 g of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (Merck) was inserted into the solution of the first step, including surfactants. The 25wt% NH4OH (Rankem) solution was dropwise added to maintain the pH at 10.5. In the next stage, the solution was stirred for 30 min at ambient temperature and then aged at 80 °C for a while of 20 h with continuous stirring. Afterward, the resulting mixture was filtered several times using hot deionized water to remove the residual surfactants and was dried at 80 °C during the night. In the last stage, the solid was calcined at 700 °C for 4 h. The wet impregnation techniques prepared the Ni and Ni-Y-Gd catalysts supported on the MgO with a 50wt% Ni loading. In this case, the prepared magnesium oxide powder was dried at 100 °C to remove the absorbed moisture. Then, a proper MgO value was added to the concentrated solution of Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Merck), Gd(NO3)3.6H2O (Merck), and Y(NO3)3.6H2O (Merck) and the final solution was dried at 80 °C and subsequently calcinated at 500 °C for 4 h (5 °C/min). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystal phases of the as-prepared catalysts were identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis using a PANalytical X'Pert-Pro-appliance containing Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation at 2θ of 5–70. The crystalline size estimation of ready samples was calculated using the Scherer equation (Eq. (1)), where β is the half-height width of the diffraction summit of the catalyst, θ is the peak angle, and λ is the wavelength of the X-ray. (1) D = 0.9 λ β COS θ Special area-related features, including the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, surface areas, and pore diameters, were performed using a Micromeritics Asap 2020 analyzer (BELSORP-mini II) at −196 °C. H2-TPR was carried out by a Micrometrics Pulse Chemisorb 2750 apparatus armed with a reducing gas and a thermal conductivity detector to check the reducibility of as-obtained fresh samples. The pure argon was used for degassing 100 mg of the powders at 250 °C for 1 h and then heated at a mixed stream of 10 %H2-Ar (30 mL/min) with a gradient rate of 10 °C/min. In the same instrument as mentioned for H2-TPR analysis, the temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) of the catalysts after the reaction was done to discern the kind of carbon species by passing a mixture of oxidizing gas stream (5 %O2 in He, 25 mL/min) over the specimen along with the rise in temperature to 900 °C with a ramping rate of 10 °C/min. Catalyst surface morphology was examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and EDX element mapping analysis with the help of the VEGA TESCAN microscope. The characterization of the accumulated carbon was investigated via Raman spectroscopy in a Takram P50C0R10 applying a laser beam excitation of λ = 532 nm and the span of 0–4000 cm−1. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation Tests to determine the catalytic performance of synthesized materials during the CH4 decomposition reaction were accomplished in a fixed-bed quartz microreactor (10 mm internal diameter) under atmospheric pressure, in the reaction temperature range 575–700 °C with steps of 25 °C, using 50 mg of catalyst (25−50 nm), GHSV of 24,000 mL/g.h and CH4:H2=15:85. Before starting any catalytic operation, pure H2 flows of 25 mL/min for 3 h at 700 °C were primarily considered for the as-obtained fresh sample reduction. Afterward, the temperature declined to the starting temperature of the test and was set to 575 °C without using another gas such as Ar. At the end of the performance test, the catalyst was cooled under pure argon with a 20 mL/min flow rate. Gaseous effluents were analyzed by online gas chromatography (GC, Younglin, 6100) with a Carboxen-1010 column. The CH4 conversion (%) was estimated via the equation of (2): (2) X C H 4 ( % ) = C H 4 ( in ) − C H 4 ( out ) C H 4 ( in ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Influence of the addition of various surfactant 3.1.1 Features of the as-synthesized catalysts Fig. 1 displays the XRD designs recorded for prepared 50Ni/MgO catalysts with various surfactants. In the XRD spectrum of the samples, the peaks in position 37.5°, 43.5°, 62.6°, 75.3°, and 79.0°, the presence of NiO (JCPDS no. 01–073–1519) is well confirmed. Also, MgO (JCPDS no. 01–075–1525) and MgNiO2(JCPDS no. 00–024–0712) solid solution phase was detected at the same angles as NiO due to similar lattice parameters such as similar valences of the Ni2+ and Mg2+ ions, ionic radius amounts (r (Ni2+)=0.07 nm and r (Mg2+)=0.065 nm), and face-centered-cubic structures [11,24]. Yoshida et al. [25] showed that NiO and MgO can create a solid solution with any percentage composition, even at a temperature of 500 °C. On the other hand, there are two types of NiO species in MgNiO2 solid solution: (1) NiO surrounded by magnesium oxide and (2) NiO surrounded by nickel oxide. The existence of low amounts of NiO in the MgNiO2 solid solution causes the NiO to be completely isolated by the MgO and cannot be easily reduced. While there is a high percentage of NiO, some of the nickel is in the second state, i.e., NiO is surrounded by NiO. Thus, huge counts of NiO can be reduced to produce large Ni particles, which can cause carbon deposition [26]. In addition, the results showed that the peaks were sharp in all samples and confirmed that the crystalline structures of the samples were close to each other. The trend observed for the crystal size calculated from Scherer's relation according to 43.5° is as PVP (29.0 nm) > CTAB (24.1 nm) > PVA (20.7 nm). The high crystallite size regarding the Ni/MgO-PVP can be due to lower PVP concentrations with more particle-particle interaction and boosted crystallite size [27]. As can be seen, the intensity of the peaks of the samples prepared with PVA has decreased compared to those prepared with PVP and CTAB surfactants, indicating the decrease in the crystal size of this sample (20.7 nm), as observed in Table 1 . Higher atomic disorder on particle surfaces may explain the lower crystallinity. When structural disorders occur, diffraction centers decline, and diffraction peaks become weak and noisy [28]. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and the pore size distribution curves of new specimens in Fig. 2 a and b have been investigated. The IUPAC standard approves type V isotherm with an H3 hysteresis ring, indicating solids with pores shaped like slits that form agglomerates [29,30]. The formation of hysteresis rings in PVA and CTAB samples seems to be at higher pressures. Also, according to the distribution in Fig. 2b, the maximum pore size distribution is focused at 0–40 nm, and samples have a mesoporous structure. Based on this figure, it can be understood that with changing surfactant, the pore-size distribution becomes broader, and the very frail distribution of pores is above 50 nm, especially for the prepared sample with CTAB, which can be owing to the attendance of the small macropores portion [31]. The impact of the sort of surfactant on the texture properties of the 50Ni/MgO catalyst is provided in Table 1. The results revealed that the BET area increased in the order of PVA (48.1 m2/g)< CTAB (50.4 m2/g)< PVP (54.0 m2/g). The sample synthesized with PVP surfactant exhibited a greater BET, lower pore volume, and pore size equal to 54.0 m2/g, 0.16 cm3/g, and 12.3 nm, respectively. It was reported that PVP may be useful in improving control, avoiding metal particle sintering, and facilitating good metal dispersion [32]. In addition, PVA is known to be a structure-directing agent that causes the formation of larger particles and less adhesion between the particles [33]. However, the usage of PVA surfactant did not possess a considerable trace of the structural properties, which led to a decrease in the BET value and an increase in the pore volume. It is believed that with the dissolving of PVA in water, a partially negative charge is present on its polar head, which the micelles are formed when the positive metal base is placed next to it. Now, regarding the relatively high value of PVA in this study and the fact that with a higher extent of PVA, the micelle's size increases with the amount of metal placed in its formed space after calcination, with oxidation of the metals in the catalyst, resulting in a decrease in the catalyst's active metal surface [34]. Regarding the reduction of the surface area by CTAB surfactant, it can be said that in the calcination stage, the CTAB was burned, and a high amount of heat and gas was freed, which can influentially destroy the pore walls and leads to a decline in the BET [35]. The TPR curves of the 50Ni/MgO materials with different surfactants are shown in Fig. 3 . The reduction profile of catalysts indicated two reduction peaks at 340- 370 °C and temperatures higher than 800 °C. The first H2 consumption peak at low temperatures can be ascribed to the reduction of NiO components with a weak interaction with the catalyst carrier. Moreover, the high-temperature summit has belonged to the reduction of nickel oxide that powerfully interacts with the support and reduction of Ni2+ ions in the MgO matrix. The attendance of this peak is an obvious mark of the excessive formation of MgNiO2 solid solution and hardening of the reduction [6,36,37]. This finding indicates that surfactants have minimal influence on the reduction of nickel species in the Ni/MgO catalyst. Moreover, no significant differences were detected in the integrated areas of the TPR peaks across the samples. However, it seems that for the Ni/MgO(PVA) sample, the peak at low temperature appeared at an almost lower temperature (340 °C), and the main summit provided a slight diminish which suggests the participation of a relatively smaller amount of NiO particles in solid solution and the rising in number of easily reducible components. This can be because of the unique structure of PVA in dispersing metal nitrates uniformly and particle size control [33,38], which more active phases were procreated via the introduction of PVA in the period of making the catalyst, which can also account for better catalytic performance for the Ni/MgO-PVA sample [39]. H2-TPR showed that the H2 uptake (Table 1) was elevated in the PVA specimen, and as a result, more hydrogen was consumed for the reduction of nickel oxide at a higher value. 3.1.2 Catalytic efficiency The CH4 decomposition process was performed over the prepared samples to survey the impact of various surfactant materials on the efficiency of the 50Ni/MgO. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the catalyst prepared with PVA exhibited a notably higher activity than the other samples. The conversion in this sample has reached a maximum value of ∼60 % at 600 °C; in addition to homogenous dispersion of the metal nitrates, the PVA controls particle size [38]. Studies have stated that polymeric surfactant PVA remarkably influences the synthesis of MgO crystals. This surfactant could be adsorbed on the crystal plane of Mg(OH)2 by hydrogen bonding with the O.H. groups linked to Mg(II) atoms. Moreover, using macromolecules such as PVA polymers prevents the particles' aggregation during the co-precipitation process so that a protective layer will be created by the adsorption of these molecules at the particles' surfaces [23,40]. However, a fall in activity was perceived for all samples beyond this temperature and is the reason for a discrepancy between the rate of carbon formation at the metal-gas interface with active phase carbon transmission and its nucleation and deposition on the nickel side, leading to the accumulation of encapsulating carbon [41]. Fig. 4b depicts the catalytic lifetime of the as-calcined samples at 600 °C. It should be noted that not only the catalytic activities of PVP and CTAB were much lower than the PVA, but also their deactivation rate was much faster than the PVA, and these catalysts, in a shorter time, approximately 50–75 min, quickly lost their activity and their stability was very poor. As a result, compared with the other catalysts, the 50Ni/MgO(PVA) sample exhibited more stability and maintained approximately stable behavior over 150 min with around 40 % conversion. The results obtained in the current work were compared with the previous studies and depicted in Table 2 . 3.1.3 Properties of the spent catalysts Fig. 5 a indicates the XRD patterns of the spent Ni/MgO catalysts with various surfactants. The presence of metallic Ni species and the graphitic carbon phase is evident at 2θ = 44.7° and 52.0° (JCPDS no. 01–087–0712) and 2θ = 26.1° and 44.7° (JCPDS no. 00–001–0640), respectively. Plus, the reflections located at 37.1°, 43.3°, 62.8°, 75.2°, and 79.1° in the XRD may be owing to the MgO (JCPDS no. 01–075–1525) or the MgNiO2 solid solution (JCPDS no. 00–024–0712) [6,46]. The intensity of these peaks has been greatly reduced in the Ni/MgO(PVA) sample which indicates the decrease in the formation of solid solution and the presence of a higher fraction of reducible nickel species (cf., TPR peaks in Fig. 3). On the other hand, the graphite peak intensity at 2θ = 26.1° for the Ni/MgO (PVA) sample is higher compared to that in the other two surfactants due to the more carbon existing on the Ni/MgO (PVA) catalyst [47]. These results corresponded with the Fig. 5b outcomes. The crystallite sizes of metallic Ni were computed from the peaks at 2θ =44.7° using the Scherrer equation and were 35.0 nm (PVA), 58.4 nm (PVP), and 43.8 nm (CTAB). The crystallite size of the aged Ni/MgO(PVA) sample is smaller than the other samples. It can be due to lower accumulation and sintering of Ni species during the stability test. The content of the carbon formation is calculated by the carbon balance over all the prepared catalysts. As presented in Fig. 5b, the rising amount of carbon produced by the sample containing PVA at 600 °C is the reason for the better performance of this sample. Raman spectra of deposited carbons derived from CH4 decomposition at 600 °C on spent Ni/MgO specimens made with variant surfactants are compared in Fig. 5c to assess and graphitize the filamentous carbon formed and determine its crystallinity. Raman spectra of materials indicate two original bands, D and G, at around 1335–1345 cm−1 and 1567–1577 cm−1, separately. The D strip is determined for disorder or defects in the graphite lattice with the vibration of the sp3 hybridized carbon atom and the attendance of other carbonaceous substances. In contrast, the G strip introduces the presentation of ordered graphite, which occurs from the network of stretching vibrations of C-C of pairs of sp2 carbons [6,14,48]. The marked two bands by D' and G' belong to the graphene layers (the single-layered graphene sheets) in the two-dimensional phonon path. Two bands with a lower intensity than D and G confirm that only several layers of graphene sheets are visible on the D and G bands [12]. The peak intensity ratio (ID/IG) of the d- and G-strips can be ascribed to the degree of crystallinity and graphitization and the presence of defects in carbon species [14]. The ID/IG values of the used samples declined in the following sequence: 1.27 (CTAB), 1.19 (PVP), and 1.12 (PVA). The 50Ni/MgO (CTAB) sample exhibited a higher ID/IG value equal to 1.27, which is linked to the poor crystallinity of filamentous carbon. Conversely, the spent Ni/MgO (PVA) catalyst indicated a minimum value equal to 1.12 which based on performance test results; this sample is less inactive in CH4 decomposition than the other specimen. As mentioned in the previous literature, catalysts can be deactivated by covering their active sites with encapsulated and disordered carbon [14,49]. 3.2 Influence of the addition of various promoters 3.2.1 Features of the as-synthesized catalysts Fig. 6 indicates the XRD patterns of the MgO (PVA) support and the 50Ni/MgO models prepared with various promoters. In the MgO support and other prepared catalysts, the MgO phase (JCPDS no. 01–075–1525) is observed at 2-theta values of 37.1°, 43.1°, 62.6°, 75.1°, and 79.1°. For the catalyst synthesized with various promoters, the NiO and MgNiO2 solid solutions are searched at similar MgO angles with reference codes JCPDS no. 01–073–1519 and JCPDS no. 00–024–0712, respectively. The higher intensity and sharpening of diffraction peaks after adding Ni to the MgO support and re-calcination indicate the crystal growth and particle agglomeration during the impregnation process. There was no gadolinium oxides phase, and only the Gd2Ni15 phase (JCPDS no. 00–015–0423) was detected at 2θ= 37.1°, 43.0°, and 62.6° in the 50Ni-5Gd/MgO sample. Neither Y2O3 is sighted in specimens containing yttrium. It is confirmation of the high dispersion of Y, suitable mixing of phases within the bulk mixture within the making and calcination, or the low amount of yttrium [15,36,50]. The NiO crystallite size of the samples was calculated using the Scherrer equation and is given in Table 3 . Based on the XRD curves and table results, it is found that the crystallite size (according to 43.1°) generally declined in the presence of the dopants. The forbidding of NiO aggregation is linked to finer particles next to the promoter. Plus, with the rise in Y to 5 %, the smallest crystal size has been achieved, and when Y content exceeds 5 %, the largest one is seen. The sizes of the nickel oxide crystals were 16.1 nm (5Y) < 18.1 nm (5Gd) < 20.7 nm (parent) < 21.3 nm (2.5Y) < 28.9 nm (10Y) in ascending order. Fig. 7 a and b indicate the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and the pore size distribution of as-calcined specimens with various dopants. The N2 isotherms display a sort-V identity with an H3-hysteresis ring. Also, the sort of isotherm was not influenced by the introduction of the promoters. Among the promoted catalysts, the 2.5Y- or 5Gd-doped catalyst exhibited the formation of rings at relatively higher pressures. As visible in Fig. 7b, the distribution is concentrated in the 0 to 40 nm span, and the samples have meso and macropores structures. By increasing the weight percentage of yttrium from 5 % to 10 %, the intensity of the peaks decreased. Some broadening in the pore size distribution was observed, which can be attributed to the filling and obstruction of some pores, the collapse of the mesostructured carrier after the addition of promoters, and a drop in surface area [13]. The list of the structural characteristics of the samples, according to Table 3, represents that every dopant has created an increment in BET and a decrease in pore size. However, the doping of Gd rare earth metal had a scarce rise in the BET, owing to some surfaces' structural extension, the action of the Gd as a spacer, creating an obstacle amongst the NiO species and preventing sintering [51,52]. On the other hand, a trend of decrease in the BET along with an increase was observed with the introduction of the Y promoter, i.e., the order of decrease in surface area was Ni-2.5Y/MgO (40.8 m2/g) < Ni-10Y/MgO (49.1 m2/g) < Ni-5Y/MgO (64.7 m2/g). So, raising the amount of Y to 10 % has led to the pore filling and partial coverage of the catalyst surface by metal particles and the local collapse of mesopores, resulting in a drop in the surface area to 49.1 m2/g. Although, the 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst demonstrated a higher surface area (64.7 m2/g) and smaller pore size (13.8 nm). This issue confirms the enhancement of Ni particles' dispersion and the decline of metals' agglomeration. The reducibility of the without promoter and Ni-M/MgO (M= Y and Gd) catalysts was checked via the H2-TPR analysis and presented in Fig. 8 . As mentioned earlier, the 50Ni/MgO catalyst indicated two reduction peaks at a range of 340–370 °C and temperature higher than 800 °C. In addition, all promoted catalysts presented two main reduction peaks. The peaks observed at temperatures lower than 500 °C are the reduction of surface NiO particles weakly interacting with the carrier. In contrast, the broad reduction peaks in the range of 650–700 °C indicate a moderate interaction of NiO and Ni2+ reduction in the external most layer and sub-surface layers of the MgO network [6,31,37]. The incorporation of Y-Gd-dopants has a remarkable impact on the reduction of catalysts. In all curves, the Tmaximum of the original reduction summit was shifted to a lower temperature. In the case of Ni/MgO samples containing Y2O3 promoter, an enhancement in the severity of the peak is visible. The decline of the components-carrier interaction, the attendance of a roughly smaller value of NiO forms in MgNiO2 solution, and subsequently, the boost in the amount of easily nickel oxide-reducible particles caused by this observation [6,31]. This may be assumed because the attendance of Y and Gd led to amending the oxide volume and diminished the lattice strain, maintaining a balance of O2 between the surface and bulk. So, catching O2 from NiO by promoters could help the reduction [53,54]. The Gd2O3 phases commonly cannot be reduced to Gd metal at the span of temperature checked for TPR (i.e., up to 1000 °C) [19]. Furthermore, when the Y content exceeded 2.5 %, the Tmax reduction peaks immigrated leftward. The peak is made with higher intensity, indicating greater H2 uptake, considerable NiO reduction, and increased catalytic performance [9,31]. The hydrogen consumption of the Y and Gd catalysts was more than that of the Ni/MgO sample (Table 3). Besides, the Ni-Y catalysts with greater BET consumed more quantities of hydrogen during the reduction process, reinforcing the formation of reducible NiO species. Fig. 9 demonstrates the SEM shapes and EDX spectrum of the fresh 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst. These images confirm a relatively rough surface with cube-like particles. There are no pollutants or other impurities in the catalyst, which indicates the high purity of the prepared catalyst. Also, Ni, Y, and Mg peaks have been detected as the main elements. Furthermore, the particle size distribution (Fig. 9d) was acquired using SEM pictures and Digimizer software. The distributions indicated that the particle size scale is frequently toward 25–40 nm, confirming the positive influence of Y2O3 and fine-size particles. 3.2.2 Catalytic efficiency The catalytic performance of the optimum sample promoted with Gd and Y in terms of the CH4 conversion was evaluated at 575–700 °C, and GHSV=24,000 mL/h.g (Fig. 10 a). A comparison in the performance of the original and Y samples illustrated that the presence of the Y promoter and an increase in its loading to 10 % end in a rise in conversion. On the other hand, with the increment in temperature, an activity drop was observed in all samples except for 50Ni-5Y/MgO, so a maximum conversion of 75 % was achieved on the 50Ni-5Y/MgO at 675 °C. Although other samples had an almost unfavorable performance at high temperatures, especially 700 °C, this catalyst maintained its conversion at all investigated temperatures and obtained 60 % conversion at 700 °C which is due to the synergetic effect of Y2O3 and Ni metals in preventing metal sintering and carbon deposition via controlling NiO reducibility and dispersion [55–57]. Therefore, in the presence of 5Y, catalytic activity was improved without any significant deactivation. The addition of Gd (5 %) to the parent sample caused a decrease in the catalytic activity. However, it is necessary to mention that contrasted to the un-doped catalyst, and this sample indicated better activity at high temperatures to 625 °C (55 %). By varying the promoter, the short-time stability in terms of CH4 conversion was investigated against the time on the stream (Fig. 10b). The results of this comparison indicated that all catalysts except the bare sample and when the Y content was insufficient (2.5 %) have excellent stability in 300 min of reaction and besides, incrementing the Y loading has led to an increase in the lifetime of the catalyst. Also, the sample containing Gd represented a decline in performance after 200 min from the start of the reaction. However, the conversion in 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst remained stable at 60 %. The better performance is probably due to the high BET, low pore measure, and NiO crystal size [58,59], as was spoken in Table 2. A decline in the lifetime of the 60 % Ni-5 %Mn-5 %Ru/Al2O3 sample at 240 min with GHSV= 24,000 mL/g.h was observed by Wang et al. [60]. Table 4 compares the performance of the promoted Ni-based catalysts. 3.2.3 Properties of the secondhand catalysts The micrograph of the carbon created over the spent 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst after the reaction at 600 οC is shown in Fig. 11 . The catalyst's deactivation is caused by the deposition of carbon [65]. Based on the micrograph, a high population of interwoven filaments was observed. It should be mentioned that the direction of carbon growth paths was relatively accidental and can be because of the competitive environment during carbon formation. Thus, it was difficult to determine the length of carbon fibers due to the interweaving form [66]. Comparing the images demonstrates that adding the Y promoter enhanced the mean diameter length and nanofibers quantity. That is, more methane was decomposed in the used 50Ni-5Y/MgO sample. The catalyst particles are also located at the tips of the carbon fibers, which indicate that the carbon fibers start to grow from the metal particles, and the tip growth mechanism is the dominant mechanism in forming carbon fibers. Fig. 11c shows the EDS spectrum of the used 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst after 300 min of methane thermocatalytic decomposition reaction at 600 °C. As can be seen, the presence of carbon is proven. Besides, the carbon peak is higher than other peaks, representing the presence of carbon deposited [67]. The XRD patterns of the used catalysts with various promoters are displayed in Fig. 12 a. The peaks located at 44.7°, 52.0°, and 76.4° were associated with metallic Ni species (JCPDS no. 01–087–0712). The diffraction peaks attributed to the graphitic carbon phase (JCPDS no. 00–001–0640) appeared at 2θ = 26.1° and 44.8°. The graphite peak intensity at 2θ = 26.1° for the Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst is higher due to the more carbon existing on this sample and better catalytic performance. The crystallite sizes were also calculated by Eq. (1) based on the peaks located at 2θ = 44.7°, which is equal to 35.0 nm (Ni/MgO), 43.8 nm (Ni-2.5Y/MgO), 19.4 nm (Ni-5Y/MgO), 87.6 nm (Ni-10Y/MgO), and 86.3 nm (Ni-5Gd/MgO). The larger crystal size and greater intensity of the metallic Ni peak in the Ni-10Y/MgO sample indicate the further sintering of nickel species [62]. The TPO profiles of the spent 50Ni/MgO and 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 12b. For both samples, only one oxidation peak at ∼650 °C is observed, which is related to filamentous carbon [31]. As can be seen, the intensity of this peak for the sample containing the Y2O3 promoter is higher than that of the parent sample, confirming the higher amount of carbon formed. This can be attributed to its high ability to decompose methane, suggesting that nickel species were not encapsulated by formed carbon. Santos et al. [68] believed this might be owing to the Y2O3 presence. The enhancement in the amount of carbon (Fig. 12c) at all samples except the dopant-free sample and 50Ni-2.5Y/MgO is in agreement with the stability test at 600 °C and means the more H2 and carbon formed from methane (This amount was more for 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst). Fig. 12d illustrates the Raman spectra of spent Ni-M/MgO (M = Y and Gd) catalysts at the reaction temperature of 600 °C. Two major bands, D and G, are located around 1340–1351 cm−1 and 1577–1582 cm−1, respectively. In Fig. 12d, the band statuses are the same even after Y introduction and can be the reason for the similar character and morphology of the carbon [14]. The ratio of ID/IG was computed to 1.04, 1.08, 1.17, and 0.95 for 2.5Y, 5Y, 10Y, and 5Gd-doped catalysts, respectively. Thus, the production of carbon with various crystallinity can arise over the dopant specimens. The value of ID/IG decreased with the addition of the promoters to the 50Ni/MgO sample, which suggested that the amount of well-ordered graphitic carbon was incremented or the amount of defective carbon species declined [14,69]. However, increasing the loading of Y beyond 5 % led to growth in the ID/IG to 1.17 and could represent the negligible crystallinity of filamentous carbon over this specimen [14]. The Raman spectra results corresponded to the catalytic performance of the 50Ni-5Y/MgO; this catalyst has been more stable in methane decomposition than other samples. 3.3 Influence of the GHSV and feed ratio The influence of the GHSV and feed (CH4/N2) molar ratio on the methane conversion of the 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst was checked. The results based on Fig. 13 a confirmed that the increase in GHSV led to a decline in the CH4 conversion, which is owing to the diminished contact time between the reactants and the surface of the catalyst and consequently decreasing the amount of adsorbed CH4 at higher GHSV. However, the stability of the catalyst did not decrease over time. Fig. 13b displays that the rise in the CH4/N2 molar ratio reduced the catalytic activity due to a decrease in the number of accessible active sites per methane entrance molecule [36]. 4 Conclusion In the present survey, MgO was selected as support for the Ni catalyst, which was prepared via a surfactant-aided co-precipitation technique using several precipitants containing PVA, CTAB, and PVP. This article delves into discussing the catalytic properties and performance of the 50 %Ni/MgO catalyst with rare earth promoters (Y and Gd) doping, aiming to compare and enhance CH4 conversion. According to the texture properties results, BET area increased in the order: PVA (48.1 m2/g)< CTAB (50.4 m2/g)< PVP (54.0 m2/g). The results demonstrated that the maximum CH4 conversion of about 60 % at 600 °C with GHSV of 24,000 mL/g.h was obtained over the catalyst made with PVA, which is related to the role of PVA in avoiding metal particle sintering and good dispersion of the metal nitrates. Also, growth in the BET area was observed after adding the dopant. Meanwhile, the sample containing 5 %Y acknowledges the higher surface area (64.7 m2/g), low pore size (13.8 nm), and crystal size (16.1 nm). Investigating the catalytic performance also showed that 5 % Y doping caused CH4 conversion to increase with rising temperature and arrived at ca. 75 % at 675 °C, which is due to the high surface area, low pore size, NiO crystal size, better reducibility, and synergetic effect of Y2O3 and Ni metals in preventing metal sintering and carbon deposition via controlling NiO reducibility and dispersion. Moreover, no loss was observed for the mentioned sample throughout 300 min of reaction, and the 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst was catalytically active and stable. The outcomes of TPO and Raman properties approved that the filamentary carbon was produced over the 50Ni-5Y/MgO sample, and the carbon generated over this catalyst indicated the greatest degree of crystallinity. coredata.dc:description: This paper describes the properties and performance of the Ni/MgO catalysts fabricated via the surfactant-aided co-precipitation technique by diverse precipitants like PVA, CTAB, and PVP. Among the surfactants adopted, PVA was the most effective and indicated a high catalytic potential of about 60 % at 600 °C with GHSV of 24,000 mL/g.h. The XRD, BET, SEM-EDX, H2-TPR, TPO, and Raman techniques were extensively applied to estimate the structural properties of the as-prepared catalysts. The other goal of this study was the evaluation of the effect of the promotion of Ni-based catalysts by selected rare earth metals, Y (2.5 5, 10 wt%) and Gd, on the activity of Ni/MgO catalyst in the methane decomposition process, which has not been widely investigated in this process. The obtained results revealed that the Gd promoter did not provide structural and performance advantages. The results of the BET area related to the introduction of promoters showed that the 50Ni-5Y/MgO catalyst possesses a large surface area (64.7 m2/g), low pore size (13.8 nm), and crystal size (16.1 nm). The result also displays that a maximum CH4 conversion of about 75 % was obtained for this sample at 675 °C and has an excellent lifetime in 300 min of reaction. In addition, the Raman spectra indicated the attendance of the ordered filamentous carbon with nice crystallinity on the bed of the 50Ni-5Y/MgO.
